body: I'll do this as part of making rclone an official B2 integration

---Has this been added? Support for Large files---

I see it hasn't been added. Hope to see it added soon! :+1:  Really need this! :smiley: 

rclone v1.29
CentOS 6.7
@i2plover not yet, sorry but it is on the list for the next release :-)
@ncw Okay good :) Because I REALLY need this added. I need to backup my servers with it to B2, but the tar files are way over allowed size, so need the Large File support added.
Any progress on this? Really really needing it :+1:
I need this as well. Is there a branch we can pull and take a look/help?

I'm intending to do this and submit rclone for b2 integration soon, however events keep catching up with me!

Any help would be much appreciated, so if anyone wants to help I can give pointers.
I'd love to see this too :)

Here is the first attempt at large file support. Any files over 5GB it will upload in chunks.  You can set the threshold for chunk uploading with `--b2-upload-cutoff` and the size of chunks with `--b2-chunk-size`.  Note that the chunks are buffered in memory so don't make them too big!  96M is the default (the minimum is 100,000,000 bytes).

You can test with files < 5GB by using `--b2-upload-cutoff 100M` say.

http://pub.rclone.org/v1.29-1-gbb75d80-58-g8139881%CE%B2/

Interested in any feedback - send a log file with `-v` if you find a problem!

Thanks

Nick

Thanks @ncw for rolling out this feature. I'll give this a try and report back!

edit: first thing I found is that after I get a 503 error (c001_v0001026_t0017 is too busy (503 service_unavailable) is that it continues but the progress is reset while the "transferred" counter goes on. Which one should I believe? Did it restart the complete upload or did it restart the chunk?

It started over apparently.. hmm. Retrying with -v set, it seems it continues, it just retries the chunk. Seems like it's doing this on one thread though. For me that takes too long though (getting around 4MB/s up) compared to 30 - 40MB/s when using the CLI tool by Backblaze ([see here](https://www.backblaze.com/b2/docs/quick_command_line.html))

issue.title: b2: self certify the integration

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
[Integration checklist](https://www.backblaze.com/b2/docs/integration_checklist.html)

Then submit the integration

Note also changes in [beta release notes](https://help.backblaze.com/hc/en-us/articles/217666858-B2-Beta-Release-Notes)

Things to do
- [x] [Large file upload](https://www.backblaze.com/blog/b2-big-data-big-files/) - Done in #456 
  - [x] Change upload cutoff to 200MB as recommended in the integration checklist
- [x] Add test flags and exercise them
  - [x] `X-Bz-Test-Mode: fail_some_uploads`
  - [x] `X-Bz-Test-Mode: expire_some_account_authorization_tokens`
  - [x] `X-Bz-Test-Mode: force_cap_exceeded`
- [x] Obey `Retry-After` header
- [x] Check detailed error handling
- [x] Deleting file versions - see #462 
- [x] Make quota exceeded be a fatal error
- [x] Add `--b2-versions` flag to see old versions

body:
@mdeboer thanks for testing!  Yes the large file upload is single threaded at the moment.  I'll make it multi threaded in another ticket - #531.  I wanted to make it work first before making it super fast!

rclone is capable of uploading many large files at once though (see `--transfers` flag).

A 503 error should cause it to retry the chunk as you've discovered.

This code will be in the 1.30 release which will be shortly
Woot! Sorry I wasn't much help (Been busy). I have subscribed to #531 for later use. Also, B2 recommends uploading files to multiple different upload URLs. You may want to talk to them about that.
@ZacharyDuBois No problems!  B2 now enforce a different upload URL per thread and rclone does that already :-)

I more so apply this to the bulk upload of smaller files (IE a whole directory or so). They said it is more efficient and better practice to use multiple upload URLs in a ticket they opened with me because my server was transferring (with rclone) using ~500-700 threads and they said it was hitting one upload URL.

EDIT: Yes, 500-700 threads because I was uploading ~4M small files (<512KB) and it would've taken forever with a small number of threads. Total data rate was ~450-770Mbps. Their current API structure needs to change to make it more RESTful and more understandable. I've been making a library (PHP & Ruby) for it and it really isn't a friendly API! :)
